Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Functional Genomics and Physiological Ecology of Seasonal Succession in Antarctic Phytoplankton: Adaptations to Light and Temperature
Award.AbstractNarration: The proposed research will investigate the genomic basis of the physiological and ecological transition of Antarctic marine phytoplankton from a cold dark winter to a warmer, brighter spring. During a field season at Palmer Station, functional genomics (using next generation sequencing technology to identify expressed genes) and in situ fluorometry (FRRF) will be integrated with classical ecological methods to investigate photosynthetic adaptation during phytoplankton species succession from late winter into spring. Using large data sets, this project will test whether amino acid usages differ based on expression. The specific objectives are (1) To characterize phytoplankton succession from the winter to spring transition, and (2) To correlate community gene expression profiles to adaptational differences among taxa. Broader impacts include training of a post doctoral researcher and two undergraduate science majors, with efforts to attract students from underrepresented groups. The P.I.s also will prepare presentations for the public, regarding research experiences, research results, and the importance of climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching hypothesis of this project is that the responses to seasonality in Antarctic Peninsula phytoplankton taxa vary significantly at the molecular level. These initial species-specific responses to vernal gradients of light and temperature will “prime the pump” for either a successful period of growth, OR species will be out competed by taxa that are more efficient adapters. The success of a species during the initiation of the spring bloom is a function of the genomic makeup of the population, a combination of the environmental variable(s) (e.g., light, temperature, UV damage) testing the organism’s ability to survive and its overall fitness to the Antarctic environment as a whole. We  addressed specific aims by examining a time series of change in community ecological parameters, species-specific cell densities, bulk physiological metrics and gene complement makeup. We performed a time-series gene expression study of community phytoplankton development over a three-month period. We added two diel studies to this seasonal examination. Finally, we captured the yearly changes in the phytoplankton community physiology using fast repetition rate fluorometry. The combined efforts provided unprecedented insights into phytoplankton at multiple relevant time-scales.

During the past year we designed and implemented an analytical framework to identify changes in the regulation of gene expression during the winter-spring transition. Our ancillary data sets included, detailed measurements of physical environmental variables (e.g., light, temperature, nutrients, water density, stratospheric ozone concentration, etc.) and temporal trends in biological parameters (e.g., species-specific cell counts, chlorophyll concentrations, phytoplankton photosynthetic potential, etc.). It has already been possible to link up- and down-regulation of specific genes on both seasonal and diurnal time scales with changes in the environment. Further analyses focused on discriminating between suites of co-regulated genes in order to assess  physiological pathways coordination to ensure success and increase fitness under changing environmental stressors.
